title: Time pickers
description: Time pickers help users select and set a specific time.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are two types of time picker: dial and input.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Time picker with dial
2. Time input
contentChunks.altText: Two examples of time pickers. The first includes the ability to type in hours and minutes, and set AM or PM, as well as use a dial to set hours or minutes. The second is smaller and just includes the ability to type in hours and minutes, and set AM or PM

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)In progress
M2 guideline – Time pickersAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposePlanned
FlutterPlanned
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Time pickers help users select and set a specific time
  • Input types are flexible in order to account for a range of use cases and contexts
  • Time can be selected without significant adjustment of one’s hand position on a mobile device
What's new
• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color

contentChunks.footer: Time pickers (including the time input configuration shown here) have new color mappings.
contentChunks.altText: Time input allowing a user to set the hours, minutes, and AM or PM

contentChunks.footer: M2: Time pickers had default color mapping.
M3: Time pickers have updated color mapping.

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.
Time picker dial

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents
Usage
Anatomy

Responsive layout
Behavior

contentChunks.footer: Dial selector time picker for a 12 hour clock.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Time pickers allow people to enter a specific time value. They’re displayed in dialogs and can be used to select hours, minutes, or periods of time.

They can be used for a wide range of scenarios. Common use cases include:

  • Setting an alarm
  • Scheduling a meeting

Time pickers are not ideal for nuanced or granular time selection, such as milliseconds for a stopwatch application.

contentChunks.footer: Hour selection in a mobile calendar picker.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Time input picker

Time input pickers allow people to specify a time using keyboard numbers. This input option should be accessible from any other mobile time picker interface by tapping the keyboard icon.

contentChunks.footer: Hour input with keyboard entry.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
24 hour time selection

The dial view can be changed to reflect time selection across 24 hours. This option is set outside of the time picker component, typically through system settings.

contentChunks.footer: 24 hour dial view.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

  2. Time selector separator
  3. Input field 4. Input text

  9. Dial selector track
  10. Dial label (selected)
  11. Text buttons
  12. Icon button
  13. Dial label (unselected)
  14. Clock dial
  15. Input text (selected)
  16. Input field (selected)

1. Label (headline)
  2. Time selector separator
  3. Input field 
  4. Input text 
  5. Period selector (selected)
  6. Period selector text (selected)
  7. Container

  9. Period selector text (unselected)

  11. Icon button
  12. Input text (selected)
  13. Input field (selected)

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Like dialogs, the container should appear above other screen elements. To focus attention, surfaces behind the container have a temporary scrim overlay to make them less prominent.

contentChunks.footer: The container includes all time picker elements.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Input selector

The input selector is a unique type of text field input. It differs from typical text field inputs in that it has:

  • An added highlight to call attention to the selected field
  • A larger shape, size, and font
  • A label below the field

Hours and minutes should have separate inputs. For people using a 12 hour clock, an AM/PM selector appears to the right of minutes. For people using a 24 hour clock, the AM/PM selector should not be present.

contentChunks.footer: Input selector for a 12 hour clock.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Dial selector

Dial selectors always mimic a round watch face. Hours and minutes can be selected by tapping a number or dragging the dial selector track.

When representing a 12 hour dial, all numbers appear in the outer ring. When representing a 24 hour dial, even numbers appear in an inner ring, and odd numbers appear in the outer ring.

contentChunks.footer: Dial selector for a 12 hour clock.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Text and icon buttons

Icon buttons are used to switch between the input selector, represented by a keyboard, and the dial selector, represented by a clock.

Text buttons are used to exit the dialog (Cancel) and save the selector input (OK).

contentChunks.footer: The keyboard icon allows people to switch between the dial selector (pictured) and the input selector.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Landscape orientation

The clock dial interface adapts to a device’s orientation. In landscape mode, the stacked input and selection options are positioned side-by-side.

contentChunks.footer: Mobile time picker in landscape orientation.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

Time pickers shouldn’t be obscured by other elements.  

Time pickers should change orientation or type to ensure they aren't cropped by the edge of the screen.

Time pickers are modal windows above a scrim. This puts the time pickers at the forefront of the user's view, calling attention to make a selection of time.

contentChunks.footer: Input time picker displayed on mobile in landscape orientation where viewport height is limited.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

Time pickers can swap between orientation or type depending on device orientation and viewport constraints.  

For example, the time picker can change to landscape orientation on larger breakpoints or when viewport height is limited, to avoid scrolling the dial presentation.  

Time pickers can fallback to the input time picker when there isn’t enough vertical real estate to present the landscape orientation without scrolling.

contentChunks.footer: High density time picker displayed on mobile.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density

Don’t apply density to the time picker dial when the viewport is constrained. Instead, use an input picker.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t apply density to the time picker dial when viewport is constrained. Instead, use an input picker.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

There are two primary methods for selecting time with the mobile time picker. People can:

  • Type in a specific value in the hour and minute fields.
  • Select the hour or minute field from the text input and adjust the clock dial to simultaneously change the corresponding time field above.

contentChunks.footer: Mobile time pickers provide multiple methods of entry, from touch input through the dial (left) to text input via keyboard (right).

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Appearing and disappearing

Like other kinds of dialogs, time pickers use an enter and exit transition pattern to appear on the screen.

To exit a time picker, the input can either be confirmed (OK) or dismissed (Cancel). Interacting outside of the dialog will also dismiss the time picker. Unless one of these actions is taken, a time picker will continue to retain focus.

contentChunks.footer: OK confirms the entry and closes the dialog.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Toggle between dial and input

Tapping the keyboard icon on a mobile time picker switches the view to the input picker.

contentChunks.footer: The icon in the lower left toggles between the input picker and the dial picker.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

Time pickers should avoid scrolling, and swap component orientation or type based on device orientation or viewport size.  

Time pickers don’t scroll with elements outside of the modal window, such as the background.

contentChunks.footer: Time pickers shouldn’t scroll.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
Use cases

Users should be able to 

  • Select or enter hours/minutes, and in some cases, seconds/milliseconds, using assistive technology
  • Choose from multiple time formats including 24 hour clock view and AM/PM
  • Enter time selection manually using input fields
Interaction & style

Time pickers should allow manual time entry through text input, rather than exclusively through the dial selector. This makes it easier for those using keyboard inputs rather than touchscreens. 

If a screen is not large enough to display the dial selector, consider displaying the input selector alone. Currently for Android Views, the dial selector is always visible.

The input selector should be accessible from the dial selector via the keyboard icon. This interaction allows multiple input methods and makes the time picker accessible for assistive technology users.

contentChunks.footer: For time selection that doesn’t require a dial view, make a time input picker the default option.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Targets

Targets for dial selectors should be 48 x 48dp.

contentChunks.footer: Dial picker targets should be 48 x 48dp.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
TabFocus lands on (non-disabled) time slot
Space / Enter
Activates the (non-disabled) time slot
Labeling elements
If the input text is correctly linked, assistive tech (like a screenreader), will read the component’s role first, then the UI text.
The dial selector will read a selection of total hours, such as “hour 7 of 12.”
